concern:
TW: self harm 

I am a 5th year in college who is non-traditional student aged. I was previously academically dismissed and worked so hard to get back into my college and I did! The community college classes I took in the time between was so easy and I didn’t really learn to cultivate better habits as I was able to quickly do work and still get As, which felt good, but not the same at a 4 year college. I have been diagnosed with ADHD/ anxiety/ depression since the 5th grade and didn’t start utilizing accommodations until high school. Used them and did great. College is another story as I started to having to advocate for myself and thought all of my negative symptoms were how everyone felt and who I was. I never saw those things as barriers, but as I have gotten older, the dots have started clicking. I have been embarrassed to use my accommodations until this year because past friends made comments that it’s unfair and I took those to heart. The academic resource center purged my files upon my dismissal so it’s been a mess trying to get the correct documentation and my doctor only sent in the documentation last week even though I was asking for months. I am very frustrated as I’ve been falling behind due to my mental health rapidly declining this semester upon starting a new medication that made everything worse: insomnia, more anxiety, not taking care of myself, thoughts of unaliving myself, and started c*tting myself for a few weeks. I started to make the connection that it was my new med I started and then cut it cold Turkey and have felt better, but I’m still in a disassociative state making functioning hard. I am scared to disclose all of this as I can’t afford to medically withdraw and am supposed to graduate in the spring. I would appreciate any advice for how to handle this

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm really glad you're here today. Please feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I guess I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with everything going on right now. It’s been tough managing school along with all this other stuff.
therapist: It sounds like there's a lot on your plate right now with school and everything else. Could you tell me a bit more about what's been overwhelming for you?
client: Yeah, it's just been a mix of struggling with my mental health and trying to keep up with schoolwork. I feel like I'm constantly behind, and it's hard to catch up or even stay motivated.

It sounds like you're juggling a lot and it's taking a toll on your motivation and mental health. What do you think life might look like if you could find a way to manage these challenges more effectively?

If I could manage things better, I think I'd feel less stressed and maybe more in control of my schoolwork and my mental health. It'd be nice to actually keep up and not feel like I'm drowning all the time.

That sounds like an important change for you. Feeling more in control and less stressed could really make a difference. What do you think might be the first small step toward that vision of feeling more balanced?

I think maybe starting with actually using my accommodations could help, even though I'm kind of embarrassed about it. I've been hesitant because of what people have said in the past, but I know I need to do something different.

Using your accommodations sounds like a sensible first step, and it's great that you're considering it despite past hesitations. Based on what you've shared, possible options could include setting a time to talk with your instructors about your needs or exploring which accommodations might be most helpful right now. What are your thoughts on these options?

I think talking to my instructors could be a good starting point, but I'm nervous about how they'll react or if they'll be understanding. I definitely need to figure out which accommodations would be most helpful so I can ask for what I really need.

It's understandable to feel nervous about those conversations. It sounds like identifying helpful accommodations and preparing for these discussions are key steps for you. How do you feel about setting a specific goal to reach out to one instructor this week, and perhaps writing down your thoughts beforehand to ease your nerves?

client: That sounds like a good plan. I think writing down what I want to say could help me feel a bit more confident, and reaching out to just one instructor feels less overwhelming. I'll try to make that happen this week.

It sounds like you've set a solid goal for this week, and that's a great step forward. Reaching out to one instructor and preparing by writing down what you want to say could really help you feel more confident. Remember, utilizing your accommodations is about taking care of yourself, and you're making a choice to prioritize your well-being. I admire your courage to take this step even when it's challenging. If you feel stuck or need support, know that I'm here to help you explore any obstacles that come up. Keep focusing on these small, manageable steps, and be kind to yourself along the way. Looking forward to hearing how it goes.
Thanks, I appreciate your support. I'll do my best to reach out and see how it goes.

client: Hey, thanks for having me. I guess I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with everything going on right now. It’s been tough managing school along with all this other stuff.
therapist: therapist: It sounds like there's a lot on your plate right now with school and everything else. Could you tell me a bit more about what's been overwhelming for you?
client: client: Yeah, it's just been a mix of struggling with my mental health and trying to keep up with schoolwork. I feel like I'm constantly behind, and it's hard to catch up or even stay motivated.
therapist: It sounds like you're juggling a lot and it's taking a toll on your motivation and mental health. What do you think life might look like if you could find a way to manage these challenges more effectively?
client: If I could manage things better, I think I'd feel less stressed and maybe more in control of my schoolwork and my mental health. It'd be nice to actually keep up and not feel like I'm drowning all the time.
therapist: That sounds like an important change for you. Feeling more in control and less stressed could really make a difference. What do you think might be the first small step toward that vision of feeling more balanced?
client: I think maybe starting with actually using my accommodations could help, even though I'm kind of embarrassed about it. I've been hesitant because of what people have said in the past, but I know I need to do something different.
therapist: Using your accommodations sounds like a sensible first step, and it's great that you're considering it despite past hesitations. Based on what you've shared, possible options could include setting a time to talk with your instructors about your needs or exploring which accommodations might be most helpful right now. client: I think talking to my instructors could be a good starting point, but I'm nervous about how they'll react or if they'll be understanding. I definitely need to figure out which accommodations would be most helpful so I can ask for what I really need.
therapist: It's understandable to feel nervous about those conversations. It sounds like identifying helpful accommodations and preparing for these discussions are key steps for you. How do you feel about setting a specific goal to reach out to one instructor this week, and perhaps writing down your thoughts beforehand to ease your nerves?
client: client: That sounds like a good plan. I think writing down what I want to say could help me feel a bit more confident, and reaching out to just one instructor feels less overwhelming. I'll try to make that happen this week.
therapist: It sounds like you've set a solid goal for this week, and that's a great step forward. Reaching out to one instructor and preparing by writing down what you want to say could really help you feel more confident. Remember, utilizing your accommodations is about taking care of yourself, and you're making a choice to prioritize your well-being. I admire your courage to take this step even when it's challenging. If you feel stuck or need support, know that I'm here to help you explore any obstacles that come up. Keep focusing on these small, manageable steps, and be kind to yourself along the way. Looking forward to hearing how it goes.
client: Thanks, I appreciate your support. I'll do my best to reach out and see how it goes.
